It has lately become known
that two of the most successful
and important devices introduced
by the Allies in the present war
are due to Dr. Robert W. Wood,
professor of experimental physics.
They are the lachrymose or "tear"
gas, used to render the enemy
temporarily blind, and a protographic screen of a special ,type,
which is especially well suited to
the requirements of modern warfare.
Dr. Wood sent the formula for
the former to a friend in Paris
soon after the outbreak of the
war. Several weeks after submitting his plan, Dr. Wood received
word that it had been turned over
to the proper authorities. Nothing was done, however, until
three months later when the Germans began the use of poisonous
gases; since then the tear gas proposed by Dr. Wood has been used
on both sides.
The gas has a powerful effect
on the eyes, the slighest trace
closing them and starting the
tears. It is benzyl-bromide, or.
choracetone, vapor and produces
temporary blindness but not permanent injury. Its use was in
no waY" a violation of The Hague
conventions or the usages of civilization. It was Dr. Wood's idea
that the gas might be used in a
single great drive, being released
over the whole battle front simultaneously.
The other of Professor Wood's
inventions being used extensively
in the fighting on the west front
is the infra-red screen for the panchromatic plates for photography.
By the use of the screen the Allied
airmen are enabled to obtain accurate photographs of the enemy's
position, batteries, etc., right
through the thick pall of smoke
which hides them from view.

Representatives of almost every
branch of the University were
present last Wednesday afternoon
when the two flagpoles in front of
the Academic Building were dedicated to Robert Tong Layfield,
'18, who died on March 2, 1915, as
a result of an injury sustained in
football. The Hopkins battalion
participated in the ceremonies,
and a group of Layfield's relatives
and intimate friends were gathered
under the portico of the Academic
Building.
Dean Brush, standing with
bared head on the platform in
front of the building, stated in a
few opening words the meaning of
the occasion and introduced Robert
Duncan, who presented the flagpole in behalf of the students to
the University as a memorial to
Layfield. At the close of his
speech, A. C. Primrose removed
the small American flag which
veiled the bronzed tablet on the
pole given by the students, and J.
V. Brooks, captain of this year's
football team, unveiled the tablet
on the pole dedicated in memory
of Layfield by the University.
After a battalion parade and review, Dean Brush acknowledged
the presentation of Duncan and
made an inspiring speech on the
significance of the Leyfield memorial. He was followed by Dr.
Henry W. Briggs, of Wilmington,
Del., who attended Layfield all
through his lingering illness. Dr.
Briggs spoke in behalf of Mr. and
Mrs. Layfield and expressed their
gratitude.
His speech was eloquent with
praise for the first man to lose his
life at Hopkins in athletics. He
clopd with the following words:
"Again I repeat for Mr. and Mrs.
Layfield their deep sense of gratitude and appreciation for your
action today, trusting that on
every occasion in the future when
it is necessary to carry the colors
to victory, you may never want
for a son whose devotion and loyalty shall equal that of"Bob" Layfield."
The tablet on the pole given by
the students reads as shown below:
In Memory Of
ROBERT TONG LAYFIELD, '18

November 2, 1914

At a meeting of • the Atheltic
Board last Monday afternoon,
Henry E. Corner was re-elected
graduate manager; the managers
for next year's lacrosse and track
teams were elected, the letters for
spring sports were awarded and
other important business wag enacted.
Stanley I. Clark,'18, was elected
manager of next season's lacrosse
team. He has been an assistant
manager of lacrosse for several
years, having served as first assistant this spring. Mitchell B.
Carroll, '19, 'Who has been assistant manager for two years, will
• be track manager next year. The
election of the baseball manager
was postponed till next fall.
Corner was re-elected graduate
manager with the understanding,
at his request, that in view of war
possibilities,the contract could be
run on a monthly basis. The past
year was Corner's first year as
graduate manager, and the financial success of the football season and the smooth working and
the progressive measures of the
Athletic Association this year
have been attributed largely to
him.
"H. M.'s" were awarded to this
year's managers of the lacrosse,
baseball and track teams—Smith,
Pitt and Duncan,respectively; and
"H's" were given to their respective captains—Knipp, Defandorf
and Siraus. In addition to these,
"H's" were given to those men
of the track team who won them
—that is, those who placed first
in a scratch event in any of the
indoor meets. They were W. A.
Weeks and W. M. Firor, captainelect of the 1918 track team.
"II's" were also warded to E.
L. Smith and E. G. Hall for faithful service with the track squad.
No letters were given to any members of the lacrosse and baseball
teams, except their captains. It
was announced, however, that the
men's record for this year will
count toward the awarding of
letters next year or whenever the
scredules are tesumed.
The elections of W. Monroe Firor as captain of next year's track
team and of Stewart Egerton as
baseball captain were approved.
A committee composed of M. B.
Carroll (chairman), W. M. Firor,
B. Russell Murphy, Alex M.
Wolfe and H. E. Corner was appointed to arrange the entertainment for the men who participate
in the P. A. L. meet, to be held

Speech on Lamartine Wins Tocqueville
Contest—Miegel and Edgett Other

Awarded to Debaters.

Joseph L. Krieger, '18, was
awarded the Tocqueville medal at
the annual contest which was held
at 12 o'clock on Friday,. May 11,
in the auditorium of the Civil Engineering Building.
A new precedent was laid down
this year when classes werd dismissed in order that the entire
student body might be admitted
to the contest. Dr. French presided, and Professor Armstrong,
Dean Brush and Professor Vincent of the faculty served as
judges.
In addition to Krieger, Charles
H. Meigel,'19, and Eugene A. Edgett, '17, qualified to take part in
the final contest. All of the
speeches represented different
viewpoints of "The Second French
Republic."
Miegel, who was the first speaker, called the French revolution of
1848 an absolute failure and proceeded to give reasons in support
of his view. His case was well
conceived and couched in plain
but forceful and effective terms.
Edgett, who spoke next, accepted his predecessor's challenge and
launched forth into an eloquent
eulogy upon the success of the
revolution of 1848. He pictured
conditions in France before the
revolution of 1848 and traced the
course of events through the revolutionary period to show that it
was a "step forward in the growth
of France for liberty and democracy."
Krieger spoke last and took a
broader and less extreme course
than either of the preceding
speakers. The tone of his speech
was expository rather than argumentative. He attributed the
revolution of 1848 to the efforts of
Louis Lamartine. He maintained
that "the purpose of the revolution was to gain a more complete
development of the sovereignty of
the people; that Lamartinewanted
to inject the republican spirit into
the monarchy without disrupting
it; and that he hoped to accomplish his purpose through public
opinion, not through revolution."
He gave a vivid description of
the revolution and attributed its
failure to the limitations of its
author—Lamartine.
While the judges were conferring, Dr. French awarded (in
spite of the fact that the debates
did not take place this spring)
the University "H" for intercollegiate debating to the members of
this year's team: Alexander A.
Steinbach, Eugene A. Edgett,
Reuben Oppenheimer, Morton K.
Rothschild, Henry C. Evans and
Robert R. Duncan.

What the Layfield Memorial Means.

The scene last Wednesday at
the dedication of the two flagpoles to Robert Tong Layfield was
one of the most impressive and inspiring the University has ever
witnessed. With the imposing,
Academic Building as a background, the lofty flagpoles aspiring skyward and flying their precious emblems, the group of relatives and intimate friends assembled beneath the stately portico and the Hopkins battalion in
line facing all these—what setting
could be more magnificent or more
significant for a dedication! All
were assembled to commenorate
the sacrifice of Robert Layfield
for Hopkins. The dean sounded the fundamental note of the ocpasion—the symbolisms and meaning of the monument to Layfield. . Through him
the University paid tribute to Layfield; through their representative, the students spoke their sincere appreciation of .hirti; and
„ through the doctor who was Layfield's constant companion in his
last battle, his relatives and
friends expressed their love for
him.
Layfield is remembered for his
indomitable spirit, his pluck, his
clean and honorable manhood, for
his many other virtues—all worthy of emulation. Those who
knew him in his dreary months of
confinement recall with admiration his radiant and hopeful smile,
his confidence of recovery and his
courageous fight to his last breath.
Those flagpoles symbolize the
firmness and loftiness of his prin-

ciples, the principles of the University, the principles of these
United States. The one bears the
flag of the University, the institution for which Layfield gave his
life; the other displays the flag of
our country, the land for which
we are prepared to sacrifice our
lives. The one signifies the inspiring motto of Johns Hopkins University, "Veritas Vos Liberabit";
the other represents the transcendent principles of the American democracy—liberty and justice.
The pole bearing this flag was
erected by the students, who,
garbed in the uniform of its defenders and imbued with the spirit
of his sacrifice, dedicated it as a
monument to Layfield and the
principles he embodied. But in a
larger sense they were dedicating
themselves to the service of their
country, pledging themselves to
supreme sacrifice for the emblem
which the memorial to Layfield
bears—the American flag.
Wells the Patriot.

The news of the death of Clifford Almon Wells, '14, first lieutenant in the Canadian Army,
came as a severe shock to his fellow-students at Hopkins. Though
a Canadian by birth, he was so
long a resident of Baltimore and
other places in the United States
that it might have been supposed
that his allegiance to his old home
was eclipsed by his devotion to
this country. Yet when Canada
was called upon by England to
sacrifice the best of its splendid
manhood, Wells, for no other reason than a high-minded sense , of
duty, gave himself to the service
of his home country. He did not
have to go. No legal obligation
compelled his return to Canada.
But his inborn love of his native
land,his lofty appreciation of duty,
bore him to the colors and won
for him in his many engagements
a commission and the high esteem
of all who had intercourse with
him. May the exalted idea of duty
which stirred him to action inspire all other Hopkins men.
A Hopkins Ambulance Unit.

If Hopkins is to have an ambulance unit no time should be lost
in mobilizing its members. The
opportunity to go to France in
this service should be ardently
welcomed by those men who are
planning to make medicine their
life-work, and who have likewise
attained the age of decision. If
there are those of conscription
age, possessing conscientious scruples, who would rather fight for
the United States by conserving
the lives of its soldiers, rather
than by destroying those of its
enemies, let them band together
and serve their country in the
same noble way that Layfield
served Hopkins and Wells served
Canada, thought let us hope that
their rewards will not be the same.

Dr. Wood sent the formula for

soon after the outbreak of the
war. Several weeks after submitting his plan, Dr. Wood received
word that it had been turned over

single great drive, being released
over the whole battle front simultaneously.
The other of Professor Wood's
inventions being used extensively
in the fighting on the west front
is the infra-red screen for the panchromatic plates for photography.
By the use of the screen the Allied
airmen are enabled to obtain accurate photographs of the enemy's
position, batteries, etc., right
through the thick pall of smoke

Speech on Lamartine Wins Tocqueville
Contest—Miegel and Edgett Other
Speakers — Uuiversity "H's."
Awarded to Debaters.

Joseph L. Krieger, '18, was
awarded the Tocqueville medal at
the annual contest which was held
at 12 o'clock on Friday,. May 11,
in the auditorium of the Civil Engineering Building.
A new precedent was laid down
this year when classes werd dismissed in order that the entire
student body might be admitted
to the contest. Dr. French presided, and Professor Armstrong,
Dean Brush and Professor Vincent of the faculty served as
judges.
In addition to Krieger, Charles
H. Meigel,'19, and Eugene A. Edgett, '17, qualified to take part in
the final contest. All of the
speeches represented different
viewpoints of "The Second French
Republic."
Miegel, who was the first speaker, called the French revolution of
1848 an absolute failure and proceeded to give reasons in support
of his view. His case was well
conceived and couched in plain
but forceful and effective terms.
Edgett, who spoke next, accepted his predecessor's challenge and
launched forth into an eloquent
eulogy upon the success of the
revolution of 1848. He pictured
conditions in France before the
revolution of 1848 and traced the
course of events through the revolutionary period to show that it
was a "step forward in the growth
of France for liberty and democracy."
Krieger spoke last and took a
broader and less extreme course
than either of the preceding
speakers. The tone of his speech
was expository rather than argumentative. He attributed the
revolution of 1848 to the efforts of
Louis Lamartine. He maintained
that "the purpose of the revolution was to gain a more complete
development of the sovereignty of
the people; that Lamartinewanted
to inject the republican spirit into
the monarchy without disrupting
it; and that he hoped to accomplish his purpose through public
opinion, not through revolution."
He gave a vivid description of
the revolution and attributed its
failure to the limitations of its
author—Lamartine.
While the judges were conferring, Dr. French awarded (in
spite of the fact that the debates
did not take place this spring)
the University "H" for intercollegiate debating to the members of
this year's team: Alexander A.
Steinbach, Eugene A. Edgett,
Reuben Oppenheimer, Morton K.
Rothschild, Henry C. Evans and
Robert R. Duncan.

What the Layfield Memorial Means.

The scene last Wednesday at
the dedication of the two flagpoles to Robert Tong Layfield was
one of the most impressive and inspiring the University has ever
witnessed. With the imposing,
Academic Building as a background, the lofty flagpoles aspiring skyward and flying their precious emblems, the group of relatives and intimate friends assembled beneath the stately portico and the Hopkins battalion in
line facing all these—what setting
could be more magnificent or more
significant for a dedication! All
were assembled to commenorate
the sacrifice of Robert Layfield
for Hopkins. The dean sounded the fundamental note of the ocpasion—the symbolisms and meaning of the monument to Layfield. . Through him
the University paid tribute to Layfield; through their representative, the students spoke their sincere appreciation of .hirti; and
„ through the doctor who was Layfield's constant companion in his
last battle, his relatives and
friends expressed their love for
him.
Layfield is remembered for his
indomitable spirit, his pluck, his
clean and honorable manhood, for
his many other virtues—all worthy of emulation. Those who
knew him in his dreary months of
confinement recall with admiration his radiant and hopeful smile,
his confidence of recovery and his
courageous fight to his last breath.
Those flagpoles symbolize the
firmness and loftiness of his prin-

ciples, the principles of the University, the principles of these
United States. The one bears the
flag of the University, the institution for which Layfield gave his
life; the other displays the flag of
our country, the land for which
we are prepared to sacrifice our
lives. The one signifies the inspiring motto of Johns Hopkins University, "Veritas Vos Liberabit";
the other represents the transcendent principles of the American democracy—liberty and justice.
The pole bearing this flag was
erected by the students, who,
garbed in the uniform of its defenders and imbued with the spirit
of his sacrifice, dedicated it as a
monument to Layfield and the
principles he embodied. But in a
larger sense they were dedicating
themselves to the service of their
country, pledging themselves to
supreme sacrifice for the emblem
which the memorial to Layfield
bears—the American flag.
Wells the Patriot.

The news of the death of Clifford Almon Wells, '14, first lieutenant in the Canadian Army,
came as a severe shock to his fellow-students at Hopkins. Though
a Canadian by birth, he was so
long a resident of Baltimore and
other places in the United States
that it might have been supposed
that his allegiance to his old home
was eclipsed by his devotion to
this country. Yet when Canada
was called upon by England to
sacrifice the best of its splendid
manhood, Wells, for no other reason than a high-minded sense , of
duty, gave himself to the service
of his home country. He did not
have to go. No legal obligation
compelled his return to Canada.
But his inborn love of his native
land,his lofty appreciation of duty,
bore him to the colors and won
for him in his many engagements
a commission and the high esteem
of all who had intercourse with
him. May the exalted idea of duty
which stirred him to action inspire all other Hopkins men.
A Hopkins Ambulance Unit.

If Hopkins is to have an ambulance unit no time should be lost
in mobilizing its members. The
opportunity to go to France in
this service should be ardently
welcomed by those men who are
planning to make medicine their
life-work, and who have likewise
attained the age of decision. If
there are those of conscription
age, possessing conscientious scruples, who would rather fight for
the United States by conserving
the lives of its soldiers, rather
than by destroying those of its
enemies, let them band together
and serve their country in the
same noble way that Layfield
served Hopkins and Wells served
Canada, thought let us hope that
their rewards will not be the same.
